title: How much money do you earn from running a bakery? - Quora

response.answer_text: To put it simply: if you want profit, keep your money in the bank, or go invest in the stock market or something. It’ll probably be less stressful and less risky. I mean it. Anyone who goes into the food service industry, especially the small food service industry, should not be thinking about profit. You could be thinking about providing a service to a community, or maybe you’re a baker who can’t see yourself doing anything else (I belong to that species of human). Don’t go into this thinking about profit. We work with very small margins (think 10%-20%), and the ones who become truly successful, become a household name, open new units, expand, etc, are very, very, increasingly few. It’s a very competitive market and only the best of the best survive the first few years. Owning a bakery is not only about baking good stuff. It’s about management. It’s about number-crunching, and people management, and crisis-solving, and leaky pipes, and broken freezers, and poring over your numbers day and night trying to cut costs while keeping your customers interested. It’s not like running any other kind of business, and one needs to know what they’re doing. I’ve learned on the job, and man, there is still a long way to go. I’m a baker, but I spend most of my days in the office staring at Excel spreadsheets. Here is a very-often cited article on restaurant failures from the School of Hotel Administration from Cornell University’s website: Why Restaurants Fail The related articles at the bottom are very interesting too. But again: if you’re thinking about profit, don’t go into this business, unless you’re absolutely confident that you know how what you’re doing – and I don’t mean the baking part. That’s the easy part, and I wish my life was just building complex tiered cakes, it would be so much easier! Good luck!
